Name: Indiana Jones: Raiders Of The Lost Ark
Indiana Jones: Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull
The Spongebob Movie: Sponge Out Of Water
Home Alone 2: Lost In New York
Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events
Wallace & Gromit: Curse of the Ware Rabbit
The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl
Fantastic Four: Rise Of The Silver Surfer
Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion,The Witch and The Wardrobe
Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl
Pirates Of The Caribbean: Dead Man’s Chest
Harold and Kumar Go To White Castle
Rise Of The Planet Of The Apes
The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty
Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay
A Million Ways To Die In The West
Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace
Star Wars: Episode II - Attack Of The Clones
Star Wars Episode III Revenge Of The Sith
The Lord Of The Rings: The Fellowship Of The Ring
The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers
Hector And The Search For Happiness
Sin City: A Dame to Kill For
Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back
Star Wars Episode VI: Return Of The Jedi
Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens
Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates
Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Pt.1
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Pt.2
Back To The Future: Part I
Back To The Future: Part II
Back To The Future: Part III
Fear and Loathing In Las Vegas
To All The Boys I've Ever Loved
Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason
He's Just Not That Into You
Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)
Once Upon A Time In Hollywood
What To Expect When You're Expecting
The Perks Of Being A Wallflower
How To Lose A Guy In 10 Days
The Boy in the Striped Pajamas
To All The Boys: Always and Forever
The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
Dune: Part One
Review: Decent, but for such a long film surpringly little happens. Great visuals and sound. Not really a standalone movie, more of a setup for Part Two."

Name: There Will Be Blood
Review: Really excellent. We see the lengths a man will go to fuelled by greed."

Name: One Flew Over The Cuckoos Nest
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb
Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby
All Quiet on the Western Front
Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget
Close Encounters of the Third Kind
Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story
The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind
Poor Things
Review: Generally loved the style and direction and was very funny, although the sex scenes got a bit excessive and felt some bits were just weird for the sake of it without actually contributing to character development or story.

Name: Godzilla Minus One
Review: Overall decent, and better storyline than the Hollywood ones, although I found the actual Godzilla creature a bit underwhelming. The bit where the plane flies into it's mouth but doesn't explode for a few seconds was very strange.

Name: Society of the Snow
Review: Very good. No corners were cut with cheap sets/CGI, the film was shot at the actual location of the real crash. It also didn't shy away from showing the gory details, so we fully appreciate what they went through.

Name: Maestro
Review: Not bad but also not particularly interesting. There was potential to explore some deep themes such as being Jewish and homosexual in the 1940s, but neither were really delved into. While the film lacks substance it does however contain strong performances from the lead actor/actress, especially Carey Mulligan, both worthy of their Oscar nominations.

Name: Dark Waters
Review: An eye-opening true story. I liked how some people from the real case appeared in the movie. Although I think some focus should have been shifted away from the trial and more time given to showing victims and how the chemicals affected their lives, to emotionally engage the viewer more.

Name: Saltburn
Review: The cinematography was beautiful, shot in 35mm it has a distinct look from its saturation and contrast. However, the movie is let down by a farfetched plot with many holes. In the end we’re left feeling unfulfilled and lacking an understanding of Oliver’s motivations, was it money, jealousy, or spitefulness?

Name: Killers of the Flower Moon
Review: Stellar performances from Dicaprio and DeNiro, as always. Classic Scorsese themes while exploring an era/culture not often portrayed in Hollywood. Wasn’t a fan of the musical score and felt it detracted from the seriousness of some of the scenes. It was surprisingly engaging for a 3.5 hour long film, but still, films this long should not be a thing.

Name: About My Father
Review: Painfully predictable. Cheesy but a few laughs nonetheless.

Name: Anatomy of a Fall
Review: An interesting twist on the classic murder mystery genre, but with only 1 suspect in this case. Phenomenal acting from all the cast. There’s a major feeling of frustration after watching this movie, as in the end there’s no explanation or twist and we don’t know how to feel about Sandra.

Name: The Iron Claw
Review: An unbelievably depressing true story. Overall very good but a bit slow in parts. Despite the extensive tragedies this story contains, there were no real tear-jerker moments, due to a lack of deep dialogue and missing emotion portrayed in the characters in some pivotal moments.

Name: The Zone of Interest
Review: Disappointing for a film with such potential. The idea was strong, to show the contrast between a concentration camp and those who live on the other side. But although we already have some understanding of the atrocities that occurred inside the camps, the viewer is never shown any of this and thus little emotion is evoked. We are left watching the mundane day-to-day lives of a household.

Name: Nyad
Review: An incredibly inspiring true story. We never really feel like we’re fully rooting for the protagonist to succeed as she’s extremely selfish and only wants what’s best for her.

Name: 99 Homes
Review: A good story of moral dilemmas and some interesting lessons about the U.S. housing crisis. Good performances from Andrew Garfield and Michael Shannon, but mediocre for the rest of the cast. Decent overall but no particularly stand out moments.

Name: Gerald's Game
Review: Usually a big fan of Stephen King adaptations, but this one falls short in so many ways. Having not read the book myself, I can’t completely comment in which ways the book and the film are to blame separately. There were some tense/scary moments, but all of these seemed to be cut short and momentum was lost. Having Jessie hallucinating after a mere half a day was just ludicrous. Some decent artistic shots involving the flashbacks was this film’s only saving grace.

Name: Defiance
Review: A different perspective on the holocaust than we are usually shown in films. We are shown the story of those who were able to fight back despite their difficult situation. Decent overall, nothing particularly amazing though.

Name: Dune: Part Two
Review: A lot better than the first instalment in many ways. A much more engaging and action-packed storyline. Visually stunning cinematography from Villeneuve, as usual. Great character played by Austin Butler, much smaller than his brother in stature and build, but somehow more intimidating and villainous. Some things didn’t really make sense though, like why does everyone fight with swords when they have access to guns and other technologically advanced weaponry, but I guess sword fights make for better action scenes.

Name: The Aviator
Review: Started very strong but really started to drag in the 2nd half. Perhaps the only film I’ve seen to depict struggles with OCD and it was interesting to see his deterioration throughout the film. At first I found the colour grading very jarring and over-the-top, but later discovered it was intentionally used to emulate the technicolor film stock that was used during that period, which in hindsight was a clever and unique technique. Although relevant to tell Hugh’s story, I found the lawsuit related sections quite dull.

Name: The Elephant Man
Review: A sad but also uplifting film as we see Joseph Merrick make the most of his difficult life, with a touching ending. Very impressive makeup and visual effects for a film from 1980.

Name: The Meg 2
Review: Poor script, bad acting, and a ridiculous plot...I expected nothing less.

Name: Filth
Review: An unsettling watch. We somehow feel both disdain and sympathy for the protagonist. The script is so unusal and spoken in thick accents that it's quite difficult to follow the dialogue and sub-plots in this film.

Name: Call Me by Your Name
Review: An extremely slow-burner. A lot of empty scenes and dialogue which don't make much sense. However, I did like the choice of location, era and music.

Name: Past Lives
Review: A simple storyline, beautifully shot on 35mm. Exceptional acting from all, but we grow to dislike Nora’s character (unapologetically abandoning Hae and her utter disregard for Arthur’s feelings are just a couple reasons), and so it’s hard to feel any sympathy for her.

Name: The Favourite
Review: Not much really happens and just simply quite dull overall.

Name: Infernal Affairs
Review: Quite difficult to follow, partly because of fast subtitles. Not particularly entertaining either.

Name: Aftersun
Review: Painfully slow and uneventful. A decent deeper story which isn’t too in your face, but also not really delved into enough for us to truly understand the characters’ emotions.

Name: Belfast
Review: Alright, but not much happened.

Name: My Friend Dahmer
Review: Not what I expected, the film focusses on Dahmer’s teenage years only, which makes for a pretty mundane story. Dahmer was portrayed to be overly eccentric and confident, which doesn’t seem factually accurate.

Name: Triangle of Sadness
Review: Started quite strong with a storyline touching on wealth & power inequalities. However, some sections of the plot didn’t seem to go anywhere, nor were they explained, such as the aftermath of the Captain’s dinner.

Name: Swiss Army Man
Review: One of the most unique and bizarre films I’ve ever seen. A lot of gags were painfully overused, such as the flatulence and erections. The role of playing a lifeless, emotionless dead body seemed perfect for Daniel Radcliffe, but he somehow managed to under deliver yet again.

Name: Where the Crawdads Sing
Review: Pretty decent overall. A sad backstory makes us understanding of Daisy’s deep fear of abandonment and how she ultimately allows a bad person in her life. Would’ve preferred a bit more focus on the actual crime, rather than just the romantic elements. Not sure why an impoverished 'swamp girl' is shown to be wearing a full-face of makeup in every scene.

Name: 500 Days of Summer
Review: Some artistic scenes in places and a unique portrayal of the story timeline, but otherwise nothing special. Zooey Deschanel again finds herself playing a character (Summer) which isn’t entirely likeable, and it’s hard to understand why Tom is so obsessed with her. It’s also not really clear why their relationship deteriorated. The revelation of Summer’s big news towards the end of the movie is really difficult to understand and not fitting with the character that has been developed throughout the movie.

Name: Tracks
Review: (Spoilers) Disappointing in so many ways. The real story may be awe-inspiring, but this isn’t well reflected in the movie and no major challenges are depicted. Robyn contradicts herself throughout the movie, by insisting she must complete the trek all by herself, yet accepts various forms of help, such as water tanks being left along the route for her. The scene with the wild charging bulls fails to carry any intensity as they are shown from a great distance away and even slow down considerably, yet for some reason they are still put down by Robyn. A painfully predictable romance ensues with her photographer, which was short lived and seemed to begin and end rather abruptly.

Name: Inside Story
Review: Obviously quite a low budget film, with pretty poor acting all around and very questionable documentary-like CGI. Still a somewhat feel-good movie and worth a watch if you have some time to kill.

Name: Dogtooth
Review: (Spoliers) As is the case with most Yorgos films, more style than substance. No explanation is given as to the motivations of the parent’s strict upbringing of their children. It’s also not really clear why the Dad arranges sexual experiences for his son, who seems to partake in it more out of routine than his own pleasure, and it gets even stranger when these encounters become incestuous.

Name: Bernie
Review: Alright, but not a particularly spectacular story to be made into a movie.

Name: The Outfit
Review: Decent first half, but storyline becomes farfetched and overly-complicated.

Name: Deathproof
Review: A slowburner but very good nonetheless. One of the only films I've seen with realistic and easy-to-follow dialogue. Classic Tarantino themes of extreme gore and an obsession with feet.

Name: Jacob's Ladder
Review: A pretty good psychological thriller where we constantly question what is reality and whether we should believe and sympathise with Jacob’s claims. However, quite a disappointing and cliche ending where the various layers of the story that unfolded now all seem rather pointless.

Was excited to see another Jack O’Connell film after his impressive role in “Unbroken”, however here he was cast into a role involving very little dialogue or opportunities to deliver a notable performance. Decent overall, but was quite confused as to who was on what side. Some tense moments which seemed to lose momentum or end rather prematurely.

Name: The Black Phone
Review: Started relatively strong but soon got a bit ridiculous. Although this film is a horror and supernatural elements are to be expected, it felt like it didn’t actually need them and could have just played with the serial killer storyline. There was also no attempt at explaining the whole black phone situation.

Name: Jurassic World: Dominion
Review: Quite painful to watch. The same plot being recycled over and over again. This film’s only saving grace was that it seemed to have less CGI and more real-world models than the other Jurassic World films. This series really needs to end, it’s painful to know another one is on the way.

Name: Kiss The Girls
Review: Started decent but got a bit farfetched. Quite a predictable twist at the end too.

Name: Carrie
Review: Quite bizarre. It seemed most of the film was just a build up to an extreme finale. Was a bit confused with the ending and lack of resolution.

Name: Demolition Man
Review: Good use of sets rather than dated CGI. Wesley Snipes makes a great bad guy. Bit confused why references to John’s daughter are included in the plot yet no attempts to identify her are made.

Name: The World's Fastest Indian
Review: An easy watch and a feel-good film for all ages. There’s not many serious twists or turns however, and the constant repeating of questions due to Burt’s hearing problems quickly becomes infuriating.

Name: It Ends With Us
Review: A unique take on the Romance genre, with some deeper topics explored. Not without its fair share of cliche/cheesy moments though.

Name: Mulholland Drive
Review: Understood the overall storyline of the movie but there were lots of scenes and details that don’t really seem to have any explanation or relevance. The over-the-top, almost theatre-like, acting works well to give you the feeling something isn’t quite right.

Name: A History of Violence
Review: Had potential but the backstory and Tom’s past life wasn’t really explored at all.

Name: Legends of the Fall
Review: A strange and complicated love story. In the end we don’t have much respect for the two main protagonists, Tristan and Susannah, given their questionable behaviour and choices throughout.

Name: Alien: Romulus
Review: (SPOILERS) A strong addition to the series. The facehugger and chest-bursting scenes are staples to the series but can feel a bit repetitive after a while. The new alien creature and style of main characters added some originality to this instalment. Could have done with some more planetary locations, rather than all the action taking place on the spaceship.

Name: The Mule
Review: Decent, enjoyable performance from Clint Eastwood. Hard to believe Earl didn’t understand for so long what he was carrying. In the end we don’t feel any sympathy for Earl as its never really explained why he was absent in his families lives for so many years.

Name: Fatal Attraction
Review: An intense thriller with a believable and well executed plot. Great performances all round.

Name: The Thin Red Line
Review: Nice cinematography and realistic action scenes in this star-studded war film. The runtime could have been a lot shorter, with the middle half dragging on for quite a while. Also, the narration was a bit too abstract and didn’t make much sense.

Name: The Greatest Of All Time
Review: A farfetched plot and over the top action scenes, but as to be expected for any Tamil movie. Quite a unique storyline and twist, although the post-credits scene was a bit silly.

Name: Fracture
Review: (SPOILERS) The film revolves around an elaborate cover up of a murder, but in the end its all unraveled by some simple technicalities in the “Double Jeopardy” law, which is hard to believe Mr. Crawford overlooked. The cliffhanger ending leaves us beyond frustrated and makes the entire film seem a bit pointless. Poor performance from Rosamund Pike, but made up for by Gosling and Hopkins.

Name: Juno
Review: Decent, but Juno is quite intolerable and its hard to understand why Mark & Vanessa would trust her.

Name: Back To Black
Review: An insightful dive into the chaotic life of the late Amy Winehouse. While honouring her legacy and talents, the film also doesn’t shy away from showing her negative sides too.

Name: Sleepers
Review: A unique and interesting story. However, was expecting a plot twist or some drama caused by the love triangle.

Name: Money Monster
Review: (SPOILERS) Such a far fetched and unrealistic plot. Lee was essentially allowed to attempt market manipulation live on TV, without any repercussions, by asking viewers to invest in IBIS under the pretence that it might save his life, even though Kyle already expressed he wasn’t interested in the money. Infact, we’re frustratingly left not knowing Kyle’s full motivations for his acts for most of the movie, until he finally reveals he simply wanted an apology from Walt, which is just bizarre and child-like. The film tries to garner sympathy for Kyle in the end, although it fails to really do so as ultimately he made his own investment decisions and also almost kills a man unnecessarily.

Name: Will & Harper
Review: The odd touching moment, but otherwise pretty boring.

Name: Blink Twice
Review: (SPOLIERS) A gripping psychological thriller with well built-up suspense throughout. Not without some major plot holes and unanswered questions though. For example, why does the perfume only erase Jess from the other girls’ memories, yet they can perfectly remember eachother. Also it’s never explained why Slater was apologising at the start of the movie and what he had done.

Name: Step Up
Review: A feel-good and easy to watch film, albeit very cheesy and predictable. Impressive dancing all round.

Name: Woman of the Hour
Review: A commendable directorial debut from Anna Kendrick. Straight and to the point, with minimal unnecessary fluff. Could have done with a bit more backstory on Rodney, as reading up later revealed a lot of interesting history.

Name: Don’t Move
Review: Terrible plot. Terrible acting. Terrible script. Just truly terrible all round.

Name: Midsommar
Review: (SPOILERS) Didn’t quite live up to its potential. Very slow and drawn out, with too many parts that just don’t add up. Soon after arriving Dani is adamant she wants to leave, but then for some reason this is never shown again and she stays willingly. Dani has a bad trip from the mushroom tea, but then bizarrely decides to take it again (or some similar psycoactive drink) later for the May queen dance competition. A huge deal is made of the fact that Simon left for the train station without Connie, yet barely an eyelid is bat when both Mark and Josh disappear in the same day.

Name: Heretic
Review: (SPOILERS) Decent, but nothing special. Starts well, with lots of well-built tension, but soon loses momentum with drawn out monologues. Too much focus on the religious elements, where the psychopathic/serial-killer themes would have been more engaging. Hugh Grant excelled in what was a very different role to his norm.

Name: The Master
Review: This film lacks an engaging storyline or sense of direction. Nothing really happens and there’s several mind-numbingly boring sequences. Somewhat rescued by its beautiful cinematography and excellent performances all round.

Name: Inside Out 2
Review: Although this sequel adds some new characters and emotions to the mix, it’s not particularly imaginative, and the novelty of the concept has worn off a little.

Name: Challengers
Review: Decent in parts but there was no real resolution or reasoning about the plot. None of the 3 main characters are particularly likeable, especially Tashi. The background house music throughout was hard to take seriously and didn’t fit at all.

Name: A Quiet Place: Day One
Review: Nothing new or exciting with this instalment. A prequel that adds absolutely nothing to the back story. There’s no explanation of how it all began or what it was like in the early days, and instead the plot revolves around a sick girl. Also, a lot that doesn’t make sense, for example why is it fine to stand near a loud fountain, yet in most cases they’re not allowed to even whisper.

Name: Twisters
Review: Surprisingly good with plenty of action and tornados. Some impressive sets for mass destruction scenes. Obviously quite over-the-top and unrealistic, but fun nonetheless. Great soundtrack.

Name: Ready Or Not
Review: Obviously this movie isn’t supposed to be taken too seriously, with a blend of horror and comedic elements, however it’s pretty poor in both departments.

Name: Gifted
Review: A decent watch, but I did find myself questioning Frank’s decisions, and Mary wasn’t particularly likeable as a main character. Also a somewhat unconvincing ending.

Name: Lucy
Review: A good concept and started strong, but got quite ridiculous in the 2nd half. The portrayed human capabilities from increased cerebral capacity are far-fetched and quite frankly silly.

Name: The Devil All The Time
Review: An interesting intertwining of multiple storylines, with a common core theme of religious extremism. A fairly slow-burner but still engaging and all character’s stories are well resolved.

Name: We Grown Now
Review: Not bad, but nothing really happens. Some nice cinematic scenes. The characters difficult lives weren’t really delved into enough with several avenues left unexplored. For example, growing up without a father, or their financial struggles, so we weren’t fully able to empathise with them.

Name: Speak No Evil
Review: A unique and gripping thriller which keeps the viewer feeling uneasy throughout. An exceptional performance from James McAvoy really elevates this movie. The main characters have us pulling out our hair on several occasions with some seriously questionable decisions.

Name: Leave The World Behind
Review: Possibly the worst film I have ever seen. Full of side stories which have no bearing on the (non-existent) plot. The film felt like the first episode of a series, with no resolution after a dull and unnecessarily long 2hr 20 runtime. Dreadful script and, with the exception of Mahershala Ali, terrible acting all round.

Name: Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire
Review: Not got many words for this one. Somehow even more over-the-top and ridiculous than expected. Kong's bionic arm was so unnecessary and takes this series to a comical level.

Name: Casino
Review: Another hit from Scorsese with an exceptional performance from Sharon Stone. Somewhat predictable and a bit slow in parts but a good watch nonetheless.

Name: Our Little Secret
Review: A silly and cheesy plot, coupled with absolutely appalling acting from all the cast, makes this movie painful to watch.

Name: Wicked
Review: Better than I was expecting. Good sets and performances. The songs can get a bit excessive though and caused some scenes to drag.

Name: Carry-On
Review: Unrealistic and not particularly tense. Can't take Jason Bateman seriously in the role of a villain and he's not remotely intimidating.

Name: Falling for Christmas
Review: Obviously just a light-hearted Christmas movie that shouldn't be taken too seriously, but still undeserving of a rating higher than this.

Name: Friday
Review: Was expecting this film to be a lot funnier than it was, but neither Chris Tucker nor Ice Cube delivered their usual levels of humour, partly due to the poor script but also their overacting of every single line.

Name: Wallace & Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl
Review: Impressive stop-motion animation as always and great to see the return of Feathers McGraw, but not as funny as previous films.

Name: Sonic the Hedgehog 3
Review: Good to see Shadow join the series. Can't complain about twice the Jim Carrey.

Name: Aloha
Review: Literally no idea what this film was about. Not even remotely entertaining, despite the star-studded cast.

Name: Kramer vs. Kramer
Review: An engaging and emotional watch, although not much happens.

Name: The Substance
Review: A unique and audacious film which redefines the Horror genre. The film climaxes with complete chaos (reminiscent of 'Carrie'), which was borderline too much, but somewhat necessary given the fairly predictable beginning and middle of the movie. Superb cinematography comprising of close-ups and good use of colour. Absolutely exceptional work from the make-up/prosthetics team.

Name: The Mauritanian
Review: An insightful look into life inside Guantanamo Bay and the harsh reality of torture being used in modern day first-world countries. However, without any solid allibi or explanation given as to Mohamedou's associations with terrorist groups, we are plagued with doubts regarding his innocence and ultimately the viewer is left lacking much sympathy for him. An exceptional performance from the relatively unknown Tahar Rahim.

Name: The Bikeriders
Review: A decent watch but doesn't really have a substantial plot. The characters lack much depth or emotions, and seem to just blindly follow the club's leader without any clear motivations.

Name: Nosferatu
Review: The majority of this Gothic film is masterfully shot in dark, moonlit scenes, with the gray-scale imagery invoking an uneasy feeling aswell as perhaps paying homage to the black-and-white original. An excellent performance from the relatively unknown Lily-Rose Depp. However, the movie lacked creativity in the horror space, using cheap jump-scares on multiple occasions and taking heavy influence from films like The Exorcist with the arched-back, spasm-filled, possession sequences.

Name: Awake
Review: An original plot and a surprising twist, although poorly executed and dreadful acting.

Name: Cocaine Bear
Review: A silly plot with some laugh-out-loud moments, but not a top-tier comedy by any means. Good casting and performances.

Name: Mother's Instinct
Review: A surprisingly unknown film considering the 2 Oscar-winning actresses in lead roles. Pretty engaging and well built tension throughout, which at times had us questioning who to believe, but was let down by the final act which felt rushed and too farfetched.

Name: Doubt
Review: (SPOILERS) An engaging story and the title of the movie has deep themes throughout. The ending leaves the viewer to their own interpretation of Sister Aloysius' doubts; is she referring to the Father's guilt, her strength in her religion or her trust in the Church system? Personally, this was a disappointing ending as there's no real resolution. Exceptional performances all around, especially from Philip Seymour Hoffman.

Name: The Sapphires
Review: A promising storyline, but quite poorly executed, with an awkwardly unfunny script, poor acting, and shoddy CGI. The girls' bond and love for eachother is highly questionable as they all show selfishness and envy throughout the movie.

Name: The Brutalist
Review: Beautiful cinematography and musical score, but overall just quite underwhelming and I'm not entirely sure what the focus or theme of the film was supposed to be. Barely any attention is given to László's Jewish or Hungarian heritage, or any consequential hardships that could bring in 1950s America. Instead the viewer is left watching the fairly mundane life of an architect embarking on a new project.

Name: The Apprentice
Review: Sebastian Stan does a convincing job of playing the young, ruthless Donald Trump, with all his mannerisms executed to a tee without being too in-your-face about it. This biopic covers business and politics, love and loss, and everything in-between.

Name: A Man Called Otto
Review: A depressing yet feel-good movie. Too many unrealistic interactions between characters made the story feel a bit forced and unnatural.

Name: Portrait of a Lady on Fire
Review: A slow and 'artsy' kind of film, which started quite strong but soon lost momentum and interest. The intentional lack of music draws all of the viewer's attention to the vivid visuals, which were a joy to watch. The storyline is simple and unique, but needed more meaningful developments or a turn of events to have kept me engaged.

Name: A Real Pain
Review: A unique film which blends comedy with sombre undertones. The exceptional writing and performances helped to develop the characters in an authentic way. Despite Benji's erratic behaviour, we grow to empathise with him as we see his deeper emotions and understand his loneliness. The camera work and colour grading were exquisite and focused on the contrast of dull shots portrayed in a rich and vibrant manner.

Name: Conclave
Review: Surprisingly engaging despite the slow pace, although the ending felt a bit out-of-place and unrealistic. Exquisitely composed shots and accompanying soundtrack. Commendable performances all round, particularly from Ralph Fiennes.

Name: Beasts of No Nation
Review: A powerful and raw look into the lives of civilians caught in the middle of a civil war. We see the formation of a child soldier after being groomed by a group of rebels and their enigmatic leader. We sympathise with Agu, despite the atrocities he commits, as he shows guilt and awareness of the immorality of his actions. Rich visuals accompanied by an excellent soundtrack.

Name: Juror #2
Review: A unique and gripping plot. We find ourselves in a moral dilemma, contemplating what we would do if we were in Justin's situation. I found myself constantly wondering how the movie will conclude, and in the end it was executed quite well, although I felt it could have benefited from a bit of a twist.

Name: I'm Still Here
Review:
What started as quite promising soon dissolved into absolute nothingness. An extremely slow-burner with very little development. We never find out what Reuben's role was as a congressman, why he and his family were detained, or what caused the country's political unrest. While I understand the movie is from his wife's point of view and how she was left in the dark as to Reuben's well-being, it's hard to engage emotionally with them as we see such little of what went on in the jail, nor do we know any of their back stories. Eunice seemingly goes back to a relatively normal life with her children after Reuben's disappearance, visiting ice cream shops and swimming in the sea, and we don't get a sense of desperation to find her husband. 
Just when some tension starts to build in some scenes it's then released immediately with no consequence. Are the men at the house going to hurt the family? No, they're playing table football with them. Is Eunice going to go through some suffering and torture in the jail? No, she's released in perfect health. Is something bad going to happen to Veroca in London? No, she returns safe and sound. While the kidnapping of a father is certainly a tragic story, the rest of it just isn't interesting enough to be adapted into a feature-length film. 
There's only so far some nice golden hour shots and great performances can salvage this movie. The cherry on the cake was a fake scene at the end to trick us into watching the credits.

Name: Escape from Pretoria
Review: A gripping prison-break thriller packed with tension. It's hard to believe the ingenuity of the escapees in this true story. Could have shown a bit more brutality from the guards to heighten the risks of being caught even more.

Name: Anora
Review: A raw and open look into the life of a sex worker tangled in an unexpected situationship disguised as true love. A truly chaotic, yet brilliant, middle section brought intensity with a touch of comedy. An excellent script with realistic dialogue and impressive performances all round really elevated this movie.

Name: Mickey 17
Review:
Started very promising with an interesting idea (albeit the underlying human-cloning concept is far from unique), but the latter half began to lose the plot and felt all over the place. The film lost focus of Mickey and his 'multiple' situation and became engrossed in a dull sub-plot revolving around colonization. While the comedic elements were enjoyable in parts, it became overdone and detracted from the more serious ethical and political undertones. 
Robert Pattinson's exaggerated American accent was hard to take seriously, nor was it necessary whatsoever given the crew's range of accents. The characters and their development were parodic at best, with Mark Ruffalo's Trump resemblance being far too in your face. 
Overall, the film was a strange mish-mash of genres and themes, failing to establish itself strongly in any category.

Name: Weekend at Bernie's
Review: A ridiculous plot filled with lots of laughs. A good blend of slapstick and dark comedy.

Name: X
Review: The classic recipe for a slasher but with nothing new brought to the table and overall just quite underwhelming. Most of the character's were unlikeable and some of their developments were odd and unnecessary, particularly Lorraine's. Pearl and Howard's motives weren't very apparent, and while I suspect this will be delved into deeper in the prequel, it resulted in this film not really working as a standalone installment.

Name: Kinds of Kindness
Review: Yorgos just put the final nail in his coffin for me. As is the case with most of his movies, overly indulgent and a case of style over substance. Three bizarre storylines where things were happening but there was no cohesion or sense to any of the plots. Rescued somewhat by the nice visuals and colour-grading.

Name: Sicario
Review: Epic soundtrack and cinematography, as expected from the Villeneuve and Deakins combo. Some great and intense scenes, but these were few and far between and overall the pacing was quite slow, leaving me wanting more. Some characters and dialogue felt a bit unnecessary and out of place.

Name: Companion
Review: A predictable plot with an interesting mix of thriller and comedy elements.

Name: Escape from Alcatraz
Review: An incredible true story of an escape from what was regarded as the world's most secure prison. The fear and consequences of being caught could have been raised further by showing more brutality from the prison guards. Would have liked to find out more about the backstories of the main characters and why they were in prison in the first place.

Name: Uncut Gems
Review: This movie depicts the hectic life of (fictional) Howard Ratner who continuously makes poor decisions and gains a lot of enemies along the way. An engaging storyline, although I didn't feel much fear towards the main debt collectors as they didn't show a lot of intimidation or violence towards Howard. There's a lot of chaotic dialogue with people talking over eachother, which is jarring at first but actually makes the characters feel more realistic. The 80s synthwave soundtrack doesn't really fit with the modern day New York setting.

Name: Warfare
Review: Refreshing to see a war movie which feels authentic and not Hollywoodized. The very slow start actually heightened the tension as we knew something was coming but didn't know when. Probably the most immersive and intense audio I've ever heard, with bass that rattled my brain. The gun shooting scenes had room for improvement, as often the soldier's seemed to aim randomly and we weren't shown their targets or if any bullets were even hitting.

Name: Sinners
Review: An interesting and unique blend of themes, mixing race, religion, music and vampires. Could have done with more backstory on the vampires, such as where they came from and what their motivations are; are they racially-driven like the Klan?

Name: The Help
Review: An insight into the world of black maids ('help') working in white households in 1960s America and the challenges that they faced. A good mix of serious themes and light-hearted humour too.

Name: I, Tonya
Review: A sad true story about the controversial career of a talented young ice-skater, retold in a documentary-style manner. A sprinkling of comedy and breaking of the fourth-wall make this an engaging and unique biopic.

Name: Life or Something Like It
Review: Lots of underdeveloped subplots and parts of the storyline which don't feel properly resolved. For example, how was Prophet Jack able to make his extremely accurate predictions, was it some supernatural gift or just coincidence. Angelina Jolie's performance is very cringe, with her constantly trying to be cute/sexy in every single scene, including even the more serious moments. The script, scene transitions and soundtrack were all a bit over the place.

Name: Falling Down
Review: A brilliantly chaotic yet simple storyline as we watch a man slowly lose his sanity while he attempts to get home for his daughter's birthday. Michael Douglas does a convincing job of playing the psychotic protagonist and ultimately leaves the viewer unsure whether to feel sympathy or disgust towards his character.

Name: The Florida Project
Review: An uncomfortable watch as we witness the lives of some of America's lower class families living in a motel just outside Disneyland. None of the characters, except Bobby, were even remotely likeable, and this coupled with the poor parenting made it difficult as a viewer to emphasise with any of them. The performances were great, but the overall lack of storyline and development really brought this film down for me.

Name: Final Destination: Bloodlines
Review: A decent addition to the series, with a slightly unique take on the classic formula. Lots of teasing of tension and insanely gory deaths, even for Final Destination standards, but too much shoddy CGI and acting for my liking.

Name: The Good Son
Review: An interesting and different role for Macaulay Culkin, and one he plays surprisingly well. The storyline had potential but the delivery lacked intensity or any nail-biting suspense. More of a melodrama than a convincing psychological drama. Some impressive real-world shots instead of using green screens or dated CGI, such as the highway and ice-skating incidents.

Name: Leave No Trace
Review: Extremely underwhelming. This movie attempts to have a deep storyline with some poignant underlying themes, such as PTSD and separation, but none of these hit particularly hard for various reasons. The protagonists choose to live in the woods, rather than this being the direct result of some misfortune. They attempt to live off the grid and to 'leave no trace', but it's hypocritical that they still make use of modern conveniences like propane and visiting a supermarket when supplies are low. The character's emotional distance and lack of gratitude towards strangers who offer help aims for realism but instead makes them unlikeable and difficult to connect with as a viewer. We're aware Will is a Veteran and likely suffered trauma with lasting effects, but this is barely delved into, nor is the absence of Tom's mother, which makes it impossible to empathise with them to any degree.

Name: Copycat
Review: What started as a decent thriller soon spiralled into a cliché 90s cop action movie. Unnecessary romance subplots and melodramatic characters drain the tension, while the killer's motives are left mostly unexplained.

Name: No Hard Feelings
Review: A few genuinely funny moments, but overall felt underwhelming. The story involves too many implausible character choices and plot developments, which makes it hard to stay emotionally invested. A light comedy that doesn’t quite land.

Name: Us
Review: A nonsensical plot and not particularly scary. An unnecessary twist at the end leaves too many unanswered questions to be effective. The film makes contrived attempts at deeper symbolism - involving white rabbits and 'Hands Across America' - that feel more superficial than meaningful. A few well-composed shots and Lupita Nyong'o's commited performance saved this movie from an even lower rating.

Name: The Witch
Review: For a film called The Witch, there wasn't a lot of witching. What begins with promise slowly turns into a moody family drama with only a touch of supernatural horror. The suspense is minimal, and the heavy period dialect makes the dialogue difficult to follow, making it hard to fully engage with the story. Ultimately, more atmosphere than substance.

Name: F1
Review:
(SPOILERS) I had high hopes for this one, but it ultimately fell flat. The cinematography and camera work were immersive, and accompanied by a nice modern soundtrack. The cameos were fun, and the integration with real Grand Prix weekends was seamless.
However, I expected more realism given Lewis Hamilton’s role as producer. Instead, we get a lead driver who intentionally causes collisions to trigger yellow flags, repeatedly disobeys team orders, and dates the team's Technical Director—all without any real consequences.
The relationship between the APXGP drivers is inconsistent: one moment they're causing a double DNF out of fierce competitiveness, the next they're sacrificing their races for each other.
Unfortunately, the film falls into the classic Hollywood formulas, complete with an unnecessary romance subplot and a cartoonish villain aiming to take over the team.

Name: The Abyss
Review: Visually ambitious and a unique take on the Sci-Fi genre with its underwater setting. However, the plot felt muddled and failed to keep me engaged. I didn't really understand the characters or the film’s core message, which left me more confused than impressed.

Name: Memories of Murder
Review: (SPOILERS) A gripping look into the lives of detectives investigating a series of murders within a unit plagued by coercion and corruption. The unresolved ending was frustrating, as without finding the killer there's no closure or understanding of their motive. But perhaps that’s the point: it mirrors the detectives’ own experience, constantly left in the dark and haunted by uncertainty.

Name: Gran Turismo
Review: A pretty decent racing movie, with some surprisingly emotional scenes. While it has its fair share of cheesy moments and cliché characters, the unique integration of video game elements and some impressive crash sequences resulted in this film beating expectations.

Name: We Live In Time
Review: Surprisingly good for a Romance. While the core plot leans on familiar themes, the way it was told with a non-chronological timeline added a layer of intrigue and kept the viewer trying to piece together the story. The ending felt slightly rushed, but strong performances from Pugh and Garfield elevate this film.

Name: Jurassic World: Rebirth
Review: (SPOILERS) Easily the strongest entry in the Jurassic World series, thanks to a streamlined plot and standout dinosaur sequences—particularly involving the Mosasaur and T-Rex. While some characters fall into cliché territory, the film generally holds together well. Several scenes appear to pay homage to the original Jurassic Park, though moments like the gas station sequence felt more like imitations than tributes, echoing the tension of the classic kitchen scene a little too closely. The introduction of mutant dinosaurs and ominous red smoke leaned heavily into 'Stranger Things' style sci-fi — something new, but somewhat out of place. Finally, yet again, far too much CGI and lacking in impressive sets or animatronic dinosaurs.

Name: Cobweb
Review: A silly plot, terrible acting, and not particularly scary. A straight up copy of the girl bent-over-backwards walk from 'The Exorcist'.

Name: Pearl
Review: A commendable slasher in a day of cheap clones. Excellent performances from Mia Goth and Tandi Wright, who created a palpable sense of tension rooted in a fractured mother-daughter dynamic. The movie steered clear from clichés and jumpscares and rather focussed on a believable unraveling of a protagonist desperate to escape a life plagued with loneliness and unfulfilled dreams. A powerful one-shot monologue from Pearl showed her emotional vulnerability and drew some empathy from the viewer.

Name: Happy Gilmore
Review: Once again, Adam Sandler fails to make me laugh in this overrated cult favourite. The humour leaned more on loud slapstick over sharp wit, and it's widely unrealistic plot made it difficult to stay invested.

Name: Weapons
Review: Zach Cregger revealed in an interview that the creation of the plot for this movie started with the hook of 17 children vanishing overnight, with the rest built backwards from there. In fact, it was very evident that this was the case, as the storyline never pieced together coherently. Why were the children weaponised? Who was their intended target? What was the relevance of the dreams? What was Aunt Gladys's motives, and what were the origins of her ritualistic practices? None of these vital questions were even remotely addressed. Instead, the movie relies on shock factor, jump scares and gore to stir superficial reactions. The intertwining of storylines worked fairly well, though some threads took too long to reveal their relevance, and at times felt like they were there purely for comedic effect - which felt unnecessary for a horror film.

Name: A Complete Unknown
Review: I went into this biopic not knowing anything about Bob Dylan or his music, but still found it fairly engaging. However, there was too much music and too little story for my liking. It very briefly touched on his struggles with fame and alcohol, but didn't delve into this deep enough for the viewer to fully emphasise with him. The back-and-forth with his love interests was confusing and a little tiring.

Name: Under The Skin
Review: A very bizarre movie with quite frankly far too much being left open to interpretation. The origins and motivations of Scarlett Johansson’s character are not addressed, which in turn makes it difficult to understand her shift in personality in the latter half of the movie. Some visually excellent sequences in the “lair” elevated this movie somewhat. But ultimately it failed in its ambition to touch on deeper topics in an abstract manor, such as misogyny and abuse, with the lack of narrative ultimately leading to it's downfall.

Name: The Lovely Bones
Review: A unique concept with the story told from the perspective of the deceased protagonist. A tragic tale ends with some resolution, albeit not exactly in the way viewers might expect. The scenes from purgatory were a bit too abstract and psychedelic-like, with poor CGI and obvious green screens. Still, the film balances tension with poignant moments, making it a decent watch.

Name: BlackBerry
Review: A hilarious yet insightful look at the meteoric rise and fall of BlackBerry. Glen Howerton steals the show as the chaotic and volatile Jim Balsillie, a personality he excels in embodying. The dynamics between Jim, Mike and Doug drives the film, with each bringing their own flawed brilliance to the table.

Name: Role Models
Review: Quite underwhelming and not particularly funny.

Name: Jarhead
Review: A good blend of serious and comedic tones gives this modern war drama a unique feel, with some striking cinematography adding to it's impact. However, a deeper look into the soldier’s back stories and their platoon's mission would have made the story more engaging. While the film leant more on the emotional toll of warfare, the slow pacing and lack of action or tension left it feeling less gripping than expected.

Name: Mr. Nobody
Review: An interesting and philosophical movie which explores how small decisions can shape vastly different outcomes. It started strong, but began to lose focus in the latter half, with excessive storyline switching and an overcomplicated ending. Some Sci-Fi elements felt a bit out of place, and surprisingly dated looking CGI for a 2009 release. Ambitious, though less cohesive and impactful than ‘The Butterfly Effect'.

Name: The Gift
Review: The first half showed promise, but the film gradually lost tension and interest. The lead performances were strong, with Gordo's character managing to appear both innocent and untrustworthy at the same time. Yet the big reveal of Simon's past secrets felt underwhelming. The jump scares were a cheap tactic for a psychological thriller, which should thrive on well built tension rather than superficial jolts. The ending leaves us questioning the full extent of Gordo's revenge, but perhaps the ambiguity is deliberate - shifting our focus from Gordo to Simon's own villainous tendencies.

Name: One Battle After Another
Review: Action meets comedy in this unconventional blockbuster. The plot was simple to follow but lacked cohesion, often leaving more questions than answers. DiCaprio and Penn deliver standout performances, perfectly capturing the chaotic energy of their characters. Highly enjoyable to watch in IMAX, with its rich colours and large aspect ratio, particularly the long rolling roads sequences.

Name: Triangle
Review: Poor writing, awful acting and dreadful CGI collide in this wannabe thriller-horror which leaves much to be desired. I felt more of a victim than the protagonist, Melissa, as I sat through the same events playing out over and over again. The film withholds any plot explanation until the final five minutes, making for an excruciatingly confusing experience — and even then, the contrived, hole-ridden conclusion offers no real sense of resolution.

Name: The Long Walk
Review:
(SPOILERS) The concept had some potential, but was poorly executed. Firstly, the origins and purpose of the competition itself are not really explained. Without sufficient context as to the current political and socio-economic state of the world, it's hard to understand why so many young men are voluntarily signing up for a competition with such slim chances of survival — and why they are all treating it so casually. Instead of paranoia, desperation, or betrayal, we largely see them joking, bonding and chatting as if it’s summer camp, with barely any sense of tension or backstabbing between them.
There was a lack of character development and backstories. We're told ‘The Major’ is bad, but not why, or what his ideology and policies are. We meet Ray’s father for a fleeting moment, before he is willing executed in front of his family, but we don't fully understand why. The story then abruptly moves on, closing off any potential depth or empathy we might have felt. 
The plot is painfully one-dimensional — a straight line from start to finish, with no layers, twists, or psychological complexity that could have elevated it. The ending feels lazy and cliché: the villain dies, one of the two main 'good guys' wins, and the credits roll with no sense of revelation or satisfaction.

Name: The Smashing Machine
Review: Undeniably an A24 production, with its distinctive cinematography and soundtrack making this a more unique fighting drama. A mixed bag of performances, with Emily Blunt in a league of her own, Dwayne Johnson commendably elevating his game with some flashes of real vulnerability, and the mostly cameo-filled supporting cast unsurprisingly falling short. Some deeper themes such as substance abuse are touched on, but overall the story is quite underwhelming and lacks any meteoric highs or devastating tragedies.

Name: Eyes Wide Shut
Review: In his final movie, Kubrick attempts to explore deep themes such as marital insecurities and unfulfilled fantasies, yet the plot is so insignificant that it falls more into an erotic drama than a psychological thriller. The repetitive and jarring piano soundtrack was clearly used for its hypnotic and dream-like qualities, but ends up more irritating than effective.

Name: Under The Silver Lake
Review: Overly abstract, leaving far too much open to interpretation. A mishmash of ideas and characters that never come together cohesively. Some stylish direction and strong performances save it from the lowest possible score.

Name: Changeling
Review: A unique plot, elevated by it being a true story. Good pacing and unraveling of Walter’s fate, whilst still leaving some mystery. Surprisingly decent performance from Angelina Jolie, and brilliant from John Malkovic as always.

Name: The Darjeeling Express
Review: Classic Wes Anderson - visually distinctive but let down by a plot involving a whole lot of nothing. Most of the movie was set on the train, by which the movie is aptly named, but it feels like a missed opportunity not to showcase more of India.

Name: Bad Teacher
Review: The occasional funny moment but largely a painful watch with a very unlikeable protagonist.

Name: The Naked Gun (2025)
Review: Fairly funny, but nothing particularly new. Some good subtle background gags, and the Snowman scene was brilliant.

Name: Karate Kid: Legends
Review: A very standard and cheesy plot which didn't bring anything new to the series. An easy watch nonetheless and always fun to see Jackie Chan back in action.

Name: Oh, Hi!
Review: Some good tension and laughs in this Thriller/Comedy, with a heavy nod to 'Gerald's Game'. The extra characters elevated the plot and humour further.

Name: Freakier Friday
Review: Very disappointing. Felt more like a cheesy Disney channel show than a serious sequel 20 years in the making. While the 4-body switch provided a new angle, it also brought a whole lot of confusion in remembering who was who. Fun cameos from lots of the original cast.

Name: Islands
Review: A slow burner with a potential hidden storyline. The core plot and it's resolution wasn't interesting enough, however. Too many empty scenes which added nothing to the storyline.

Name: The Woman in Cabin 10
Review: A decent plot which fell flat in execution. The ending was far from elegant and left unanswered questions. A weak script which tried to impress with complex sentences but ultimately strayed from realism.

Name: The Woman in the Yard
Review: I have absolutely no idea what this movie was about. Surprisingly impressive cinematography, but it wasn't enough to make up for the nonsensical plot.

Name: The Woman in the Window
Review: Didn't really follow or engage with this movie. Felt cheaply made and the sets looked more like a theatre play than a movie. A silly plot and ridiculous ending.

Name: Last Breath
Review: An interesting true story. Good underwater scenes, albeit with some poor CGI in parts. Well paced and not padded with unnecessary fluff.

Name: The Phoenician Scheme
Review: The nail in the coffin for Wes Anderson. Another nonsensical and boring movie which relies on big names to draw interest.

Name: I Know What You Did Last Summer
Review: A cheap slasher with predictable elements, but fairly fun nonetheless and kept me guessing till the end as to the identity of the killer.

Name: Pleasantville
Review: A unique concept and very well executed mix of colour and black-and-white. This film delivers deeper messages on the importance of creativity and free will for societal progression.

Name: The Forgiven
Review: A believable story and a look into class and wealth inequalities in developing countries. Not convinced by the resolution of the movie, and if forgiveness or justice were truly found.

Name: 28 Years Later
Review: Some unique concepts and new zombies introduced in this installment. The retro radio monologue combined with the heavy horn soundtrack in the early scenes built epic tension. It wasn't clear what the motivation was for Spike and his dad visiting the mainland, were they looking for resources or just there for hunting practice? The ending was strange, but I guess it was a setup for the sequel.

Name: Flow
Review: Unique and impressive animation, considering the low budget. However, I didn't engage much with the story.

Name: Anyone But You
Review: A cheesy romance with a predictable plot and minimal laughs. A painfully static performance from Sydney Sweeney.

Name: The Tourist
Review: Poor plot, poor script and poor acting.

Name: Minari
Review: A simple masterpiece. A heart-warming story of a Korean family chasing the American dream, battling through hardship and tragedy. Beautiful cinematography and a moving soundtrack. Performances are exceptional across the board, with Youn Yuh-jung picking up a well deserved Oscar.

Name: The Man from Earth
Review: A unique concept with great storytelling and dialogue, although it was difficult to look past the extremely low budget execution.
